question: Which observable property of a soil sample would best indicate high humus content?

content.source_1: Humus is the dark, stable fraction of soil organic matter; as humus accumulates in the surface (A) horizon, it typically imparts dark brown to black colors compared with underlying layers.
content.source_2: Soil survey practice uses Munsell color (low value and low chroma) of the surface horizon as a field cue for higher organic matter content; dark surface soils generally contain more organic matter than lighter ones.
content.source_3: Dark soil color can also arise from non-organic causes—such as dark parent materials (e.g., basalt/mafic minerals), manganese oxides, or charcoal/black carbon—so darkness is not uniquely diagnostic of humus.
content.source_4: Humus increases soil porosity and aggregation, lowers bulk density, and raises plant-available water; humus-rich soils are typically crumbly and spongy and retain moisture well.
content.source_5: Across soil textures, organic matter content is positively correlated with water-holding capacity, with especially strong effects in sandy soils where adding organic matter markedly increases available water.
content.source_6: Apparent soil darkness varies with moisture and observation conditions; wet soils look darker than dry soils, so relying on color alone without standardized dry/moist readings can mislead assessments of humus content.
